skill.name: scientific-brainstorming
skill.description: Research ideation partner. Generate hypotheses, explore interdisciplinary connections, challenge assumptions, develop methodologies, identify research gaps, for creative scientific problem-solving.
skill.summary: Research ideation partner. Generate hypotheses, explore interdisciplinary connections, challenge ass...
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: The skill is a text-only guidance workflow for brainstorming. No code, file access, or network actions are present. No data theft or execution patterns were detected.

content.value_statement: Research brainstorming can stall when assumptions stay hidden. This skill guides structured ideation to unlock new hypotheses and methods.
actual_capabilities: Ask probing questions to clarify research context
Generate hypothesis ideas and research directions
Challenge assumptions with reversals and constraints
Propose structured methods like SCAMPER or TRIZ
Summarize promising directions and next steps
limitations: Does not access external literature or databases
Does not run experiments or validate results
Quality depends on the detail you provide

use_cases.title: New thesis direction
use_cases.description: Explore novel hypotheses and study designs when starting a dissertation topic.

use_cases.title: Project pivot ideas
use_cases.description: Identify research gaps and alternative methodologies for stalled projects.

use_cases.title: Cross-domain concepts
use_cases.description: Find interdisciplinary analogies to spark new product research paths.

prompt_templates.title: Start the session
prompt_templates.scenario: You want to define the research problem
prompt_templates.prompt: I study [field]. My current challenge is [problem]. Ask questions to clarify context and constraints, then propose initial idea directions.

prompt_templates.title: Challenge assumptions
prompt_templates.scenario: You want a critical but creative push
prompt_templates.prompt: Here is my current model: [model]. Identify core assumptions, reverse them, and suggest alternative hypotheses.

prompt_templates.title: Apply a method
prompt_templates.scenario: You need a structured ideation tool
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the SCAMPER framework on this research method: [method]. Provide ideas for each SCAMPER step.

prompt_templates.title: Synthesize outcomes
prompt_templates.scenario: You want a concise next step plan
prompt_templates.prompt: From our brainstormed ideas: [ideas]. Synthesize themes, pick top 3 directions, and outline first experiments.

output_examples.input: I am studying soil microbiomes and want new ways to detect early drought stress.
output: Hypothesis: Microbial volatile signatures change before plant symptoms appear.
Interdisciplinary link: Use signal processing from seismology to detect weak patterns.
Method idea: Combine metabolomics with low-cost sensor arrays in field plots.
Next step: Pilot study with paired irrigated and stressed samples.

best_practices: Share constraints and available tools early
Encourage bold ideas before feasibility checks
Request a structured method when stuck
anti_patterns: Asking for factual literature reviews without providing sources
Expecting the skill to validate experimental results

faq.question: What platforms does this skill support?
faq.answer: It works in Claude, Codex, and Claude Code as a conversational skill.

faq.question: Are there limits to the ideas it can generate?
faq.answer: Yes. It depends on the details you provide and does not verify feasibility.

faq.question: Can I integrate it into a lab workflow?
faq.answer: Yes. Use it for ideation sessions and translate outputs into lab protocols.

faq.question: Does it access my data or files?
faq.answer: No. It uses only the text you provide in the chat.

faq.question: What if the ideas feel generic?
faq.answer: Provide more constraints, assumptions, and domain specifics, then rerun.

faq.question: How does it compare to a literature review?
faq.answer: It generates ideas and frameworks, but it does not search or cite sources.
